AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Botanicula
Original Release: 2012
Genre Tags: Point & Click; Adventure; Casual; Puzzle
My Overall Grade: A-
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 4-7 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Novelty seekers; Casual gamers
REVIEWBotanicula is an incredibly charming, short-and-sweet game which is frequently described as having a “happy” identity.  It is a point-and-click style, casual adventure game that takes you on a wondrous ride through a microcosmic fantasy world inhabited by bugs and critters.  Any fan of point-and-click, adventure-puzzle games will likely enjoy the experience.

The best feature of this game is the overall charm inherent in its delivery.  The art style and the soundscape together create the alluring atmosphere of the game.  The simple story is told through animations and emotion-filled sounds rather than through text and dialogue.  Despite the simple storytelling mechanics, all the characters you play and those you meet are uniquely interesting and charming.

The actual gameplay requires you to progress the story by solving puzzles via interaction with the world around you.  It will be mostly trial and error; but nothing is too daunting.  I felt the puzzles were a good balance of tricky and sensible; but they are not all necessarily logical.  You will have to think about the puzzles in terms of the wacky game-world dynamics.

The game is rather short, even shorter if you rush through the main objectives.  It is more enjoyable (and still somewhat short) if you take the time to interact with everything and see what you can discover.  There are plenty of hidden “Easter eggs” and collectibles scattered throughout the game to cater to those who enjoy treasure hunts and achievements.

Botanicula is definitely a well-designed game that was created with love and care.  I recommend that any point-and-click, adventure-puzzle gamer considering trying it.  Its charm will cater to fans of the genre both young and old.

reviewText:
I've thought about writing a review for Botanicula for a few weeks now. Aside from the fact that there are numerous apt (and more briefly stated) praises already posted here, the game has been out for a few years now.

It's an Indie, point-and-click, puzzle adventure; brought to us by the Czech creators of Samorost 1&2 and Machinarium, Amanita Design – if you enjoy either of those games, you will take delight in this. The thoroughly organic world and its inhabitants are highly imaginative, some even bizarre-looking and -sounding. Some players may consider it too succinct, or even more attuned toward children. The simple story, though solid and sweet, does not require heavy ruminations – this is a game of the senses, pure and simple. You control a group of four friends on a mission to plant a seed. The main goal on each level progresses you to the next level; the puzzles are intuitive. The price of the game, whether regular or on sale, is appropriate. Yes, it is a Flash game. (Interesting to note that I cannot enjoy tBoI or Windosill on my current PC setup without gameplay becoming bogged down almost instantly; but with Botanicula, never any bogging or catching.) Summed up: the graphics, gameplay, sound and music - all superb, A+++. What more can I say to get you to try out this lovely gem?...

There was a tremendous amount of heart put into this game, truly.

Botanicula is a visual and (emphasis on) auditory indulgence: you may think you're just going to ease into it, test the waters with your big toe; but you will be swept away and never realise it till the ride comes to its satisfyingly, cyclical conclusion. It offers a kind of cleansing and respite, whether from the mundane of the outside world, or to just step away from frenetic and adrenaline-packed L4D2 runs.

The sounds are sheer ear candy – you want to touch everything. The world is strange and wondrous: during first-time gameplay, you never know what manner of creature or environment alteration will manifest itself from your curiosity-driven touching; subsequent gameplays (for myself, anyway) do not fail to continually instill such positive feelings because the graphics, music, creatures and environment (plus their corresponding sounds) are just that sublime.

While there are, sadly, no cards to obtain from playing this game toward earning badges, the 47 in-game, animated cards more than make up for it; and count toward the game's 53 achievements. It is rewarding to collect them all (and yes, you will aspire to collect each and every one of them in every gameplay you attempt, even the time-spent Svolavac. (Though, I think there should be a card for the 3 jingle-y leaves that tumble out around your feet - other gamers like myself may know what I'm alluding to.) The names of the creatures achievements are in Czech, and punching them up into Google translate will not only add to your enjoyment, but enlighten it, as well.

The music steals you off from the word go, setting a pace perfectly harmonised to what is happening in the game, at that time. A previous reviewer here made mention of the burst of cheery song that erupts when you achieve a goal – it really does fill you with sheer happiness, no kidding... and lately, when playing L4D2, I've been thinking how cool (if a bit bizarre) it would be, hearing that tune after everyone's made it alive to the saferoom...

Definitely give it a try, if only to experience the eye and ear candy... if it doesn't turn out to be your kind of game - or you can only enjoy one gameplay - you will know someone who'll love it...

11/10

reviewText:
Short version: 79%Botanicula is an excellent voiceless surrealist point ‘n’ click adventure, a great fit in the Amanita Design library. Two extremely long chapters hold back its final score though, as they just drag on for way too long.

Long version:Before Samorost 3, Botanicula was probably the longest Amanita Design game with its 4-6 hours of play time (as opposed to the 30-120 minutes we are used from them). It is also unique in their portfolio in the sense that it has a cohesive central plot line about a group of sentient plants and their journey along the branches of a life-giving, glowing tree. Their task is no smaller than saving the last seed of their tree from an evil light-eating spider-like monster and its numerous offspring.
Still, at its core, it is a surrealist adventure, this time showcased in the many small sub-stories that form each chapter. If you are looking for all those unexplainable moments, like a random onion using a fishing rod to get a mount to ride on, you’ll find those in abundance.

While it was commendable that they tried to make a full-fledged adventure game, its size also presents a drawback. This is most notorious in the underground section, which is so full of running around that it gets actually boring. But I also could mention the city, where the usual voiceless and textless approach adds an unnecessary difficulty modifier to the often unexplained puzzles. Sometimes progress can be more of a question of luck than problem solving skills.

With all these put together, Botanicula is a strange beast, because I cannot recommend it for those who are not familiar with this studio’s games. But if you already have some experience with Amanita Design, then Botanicula may be among your favourite adventure games.

I love this game so much, it's one of my favourite games. It's not very long, but sometimes that can be a positive - the game doesn't outstay its welcome and the pacing is perfect.

This is another game by Amanita Design that incorporates non-verbal story telling and they're really good at it. There isn't a single word spoken or written throughout the game, and yet you're able to follow the story through the visuals.

The puzzles were actually quite easy by adventure game standards and I don't think I had to look anything up. There is a bit of backtracking, but not too much I felt.

All in all a pretty fantastic game, I would recommend it to anyone.

reviewText:
In this game, you play as a group of protagonists – Mr. Lantern, Mrs. Mushroom, Mr. Poppyhead, Mr. Twig, and Mr. Feather – who are trying to save their home from the spider attacks that plague it. To save your home, you must solve puzzle after puzzle, most of which are easy. I did get stuck once, though that may have been because it was getting late and I’d already been playing for a while. I picked it up the next morning and instantly figured it out.

Pros:
- This game is truly beautiful. The art style is unique, the soundtrack is incredible, and the five playable characters have so much personality without actually saying a word.
- I love how interactive this game is. Random bugs, plants, etc. can be clicked on and most give you achievements.
- The storyline is well developed, as are the minor characters. This game is filled with little whimsical moments involving the littlest things – a spider hiding behind a leaf, eggs hatching.
- Pretty sure I sat at my desk with this amazed expression on my face the whole time (the soundtrack gets to you, man!).

Cons:
- While I played through this twice (once for story, once for achievements – I’m not posting a review of anything until I 100% it), there is very little in the replay value aspect. Keep in mind if you play this that you should really pay attention and experience the story the first playthrough, because it won’t be the same the next time.
- The puzzles are very easy, which would make this a great game for younger children, but might become a bit boring for those who like a challenge.

Following the very grounded release of Machinarium, Botanicula seems much closer to Amantia Design's beginnings. Machinarium was a much more somber view of a machine's wasteland, it also used more traditional means of gameply (solve everything to continue, whether through traditiona puzzles or point and click cleverness). Botanicula is a much more vibrant world and takes a different approach to its gameplay. Though there are plenty of puzzles that can be solved without too much headscratching, there are also little secrets and optional creatures to encounter.

Botanicula is both a beautiful and strange world. Though some objects and settings are recognizable (such as a tree, seed, insects) everything is so alive and full of wonder. Accompanying the superb artwork of the game, are the sounds of Czech band DVA. The music in this game is full of suitably strange and wild tones. Chimes, bells, vocal gymnastics, strings, and just about anything else finds its way into the soundtrack. The music and sound design are perfect for this game.

Amantia Design has put together a menagerie of sights and sounds that is completely unforgettable. Botanicula is a trip well worth taking.

reviewText:
Botanicula, part of the Amanita collection, is a lovely little indie game. It's from the same studio that brought us Machinarium, so if you enjoyed that game, you'll like this too.

It's the story of a group of friends who have to band together to dispatch an evil presence threatening their home.

reviewText:
The thing that immediately stood out to me about Botanicula was how charming it is. This is due in large part to the excellent audio, both from the folktronica soundtrack and the sound effects, which incorporate a wide variety of unintelligible vocal sounds that make the game feel really lighthearted and playful. Another contributor to the charm is the animations, which are very exaggerated, like a cartoon. They are key to communicating the story and objectives since the game doesn't use text or spoken word at all. Also, the game looks pretty great; I was impressed by the large variety of creatively-designed creatures you encounter throughout the game.

On the gameplay front, it's pretty much what you would expect from a point-and-click adventure game. You are primarily clicking (or clicking and dragging) on objects in the environment in order to solve puzzles and advance through the game. In general, the puzzles are reasonably difficult; while a fair number of them were not all that challenging, a few had me stumped for quite a while. For one puzzle, I came up with a solution that I didn't think the game would acknowledge, but lo and behold, it totally worked, which was a great feeling.

A lot of adventure games become tedious when you have to cycle through your large inventory of items, trying to use them somewhere in the environment. Botanicula takes great care in reducing the need for this because you only ever have a small number of items at any one time, there are no item combinations, and for any given scene it's easy to check if an item can be used or not. I really appreciated this about Botanicula.

My gripes with the game are pretty minor. When I first started playing, differentiating between interactable objects that were just for show and ones that would help me solve a puzzle was a bit difficult. Also, the first area, where you are walking on tree branches, was too visually similar from scene to scene, which made navigating the area a bit difficult. The future areas, fortunately, greatly improve upon this.

In short, Bontanicula is a pretty great game. It never stops exuding its charm and does away with what has frustrated me about adventure games in the past.

reviewText:
This game is without question weird. And that’s definitely to its favor.
Botanicula is a point-and-click adventure game about the faunal flora residents of a fantastical tree trying to stop a dark, arachnid-like entity from destroying everything they know. If it sounds strange already, then trust me when I say you don’t know the half of it.
To begin, gameplay is standard to the genre; as the player, your job is to explore the grand extent of the tree from the dramatically miniscule perspective of your band of five oddball characters. In your adventuring, you are provided the opportunity to interact with nearly every aspect of your environment, collecting items, receiving and completing small quests and challenges, solving puzzles, and unraveling the simple and yet still fascinating narrative before you, often making use of the individual assets of your tiny arboreal team to do so, and all without the game ever uttering more than a few words of human speech in the process.
Using that as a steppingstone, I transition into aesthetics. The artwork is absolutely beautiful, reminiscent of the animated fair of Tim Burton. Yet, even as there is a bizarre and almost twisted nature to the visuals, the presentation remains almost perpetually lighthearted (most of the time). Nearly every aspect of the tree that the small band of main characters inhabits has a life of its own and each is immensely unique from one to the next (so much so, there’s even a card-collecting mechanic within the game that showcases a solid plethora of these many faces whenever the player takes interest in looking back). Meanwhile, the main team itself is an odd collective of friends who, while not given heavy character development, are filled with heart and personality. Matching up with the strange visuals and dreamlike presentation is an almost unearthly soundtrack from Czech musical group DVA, who also aided in other aspects of the final product.
As I stated earlier, there is almost no true verbal dialogue outside of the intentionally indecipherable mumbles of its characters, and next to no text of any kind; the entirety of the story is recalled and played out on screen as if on a stage. Nevertheless, it is an engaging narrative, even as it is a simple one. In the end, the game isn’t especially lengthy, nor is it predominantly difficult (I, considering myself a less impressive gamer, was able to complete it in right around 5 hours); additionally, like most games in its subset genre, it tends to be a casual experience without an exceptional abundance of high-velocity or high-intensity moments during play. Do any of these facts diminish the value of this game? My answer is an emphatic no. When approaching almost any artistic product—be it a game, a song, a movie, or anything else—it’s important to remember that rarely, if ever, will a piece of art appeal to everyone; even the most popular or widely received products will have people who simply don’t enjoy it the way others do, and this one is certainly not exempt by any means.
Botanicula is definitely a strange piece of work. It’s a wild adventure that takes place almost entirely in a tree; it’s a bizarre introduction to a lovable cast and a beautiful world; it’s a story without many words, yet it is filled with all sorts of heart and humor (sometimes irreverent—discerning gamers/parents, feel free to message me for more details); it’s a relatively calm, somewhat brief, light-hearted game that had me entranced, entertained, and engaged all the way through.
To sum it up shortly: it was pretty weird, and it was pretty awesome.

Botanicula Review\n\nBotanicula is a family friendly point-and-click adventure with some puzzles and challenges through the game.  If you are the type that appreciates presentation and art over gameplay,  Botanicula is your type of game.  The story is something about some tree dying somewhere and evil spiders have taken over or something, but story isn't too important here.  You control a group of five characters that travel together trying to save the world and during your adventure you'll run into puzzles and tasks that require completion to progress through the game.  However this is the game's best moments, in clicking environmental objects and backgrounds to see what animations will play and how the characters respond.  Your interactions are mostly with fictional bug creatures and plantlife, which really helps to develop what kind of world Botanicula is set it.  It is charming and fun at first, but halfway through the game I had to look up a walkthrough multiple times to see what to do.  It becomes a case of not what your logical thinking is, but what the devolopers had in mind when designing it, and that can stop your progress to a halt.  The puzzles, while usually frustrating, were never so hard to the point of ragequitting.  Throughout the game you will collect cards that can be viewed at any time for amusing animations and sounds based on the creatures and environments you play through.  Supposedly there is a secret ending or reward for collecting all of them, but I didn't stress myself to the point of that and don't feel motivated to play again.  Overall I do recommned Botanicula to fans of point-and-click games and to the more casual crowd of gamers.  However I don't think Botanicula is worth the full price of $10 as it isn't very long and it does have frustrating moments.  Pick it up when it's on sale or in a bundle.

Botanicula is a wonderful point-and-click game about life in a tree.

The story revolves around 5 characters who try to save their home, a tree, from black death blobs. They consist of insects or leaves or basically anything one might find in a tree, as do the other creatures they encounter.

As far as a point and click game goes, amanita design did a very good job in making sure there are lots of things to click. The setup is generally spending each level interacting with the other creatures trying to collect enough of a particular item to be able to continue. The puzzles are generally enjoyable, until you're only missing the last piece of the puzzle. Then it can get to the point of frustrated clicking of everything in sight.

This being a point and click game, if you are able to stream to/play on a tablet device, you should do so.

The graphics in this game are really nice and really do bring the game to life. It never looks as if the environment is static, and the design of even the smallest creature is very well thought out and executed.

The music is rather bizarre, but it is by no means bad. It changes as you complete puzzles, and as creatures make sound. This helps to enhance the feel of the environment set up by the graphics. But admittedly the music might be an acquired taste.

I could find no bugs in this game. The menu layout is somewhat odd, though. Remember to make good use of your save slots.

While it may not take the longest time to complete this game, it is definitely worth a buy if you're a fan of amanita games, or just quirky games in general.

reviewText: Amazing psychedelic puzzle game dream with a great soundtrack!! A Masterpiece, Have fun & enjoy exploring!

Botanicula is a wonderful point-and-click game about life in a tree.

The story revolves around 5 characters who try to save their home, a tree, from black death blobs. They consist of insects or leaves or basically anything one might find in a tree, as do the other creatures they encounter.

As far as a point and click game goes, amanita design did a very good job in making sure there are lots of things to click. The setup is generally spending each level interacting with the other creatures trying to collect enough of a particular item to be able to continue. The puzzles are generally enjoyable, until you're only missing the last piece of the puzzle. Then it can get to the point of frustrated clicking of everything in sight.

This being a point and click game, if you are able to stream to/play on a tablet device, you should do so.

The graphics in this game are really nice and really do bring the game to life. It never looks as if the environment is static, and the design of even the smallest creature is very well thought out and executed.

The music is rather bizarre, but it is by no means bad. It changes as you complete puzzles, and as creatures make sound. This helps to enhance the feel of the environment set up by the graphics. But admittedly the music might be an acquired taste.

I could find no bugs in this game. The menu layout is somewhat odd, though. Remember to make good use of your save slots.

While it may not take the longest time to complete this game, it is definitely worth a buy if you're a fan of amanita games, or just quirky games in general.

reviewText:
Botanicula is an interesting and beautiful game. It doesn't have much in the way of gameplay but it manages to have just enough to engage the player, separating it from gimmicky games like Mountain.

The art style is strange but fun, the music is relaxing and pleasant, and the story is woven around you without a single ounce of spoken dialogue. Probably because it's an indie game and they couldn't afford voice actors, but I prefer it this way to begin with!

On the downside the ending feels very rushed and in several areas of the game mechanics are introduced once, used once to retrieve a necessary object, and then forgotten about. The ending gameplay areas feel very rushed and a little sloppy. It has all the benefits of an artsy game, but it comes with the downsides of being a budget game.

As a gamer I'm satisfied with the $10 bill I paid to play this game and would recommend it at that price or lower. You can watch my let's play of the game below to see if the game is right for you, though I do warn you that if you get lost in the music too much you'll forever be trapped.

http://youtu.be/fBf7vNtwSzc

If I were to describe this game with one word, it would be: adorable. Botanicula is a simple, funny and lighthearted tale about many, many creatures, whose peaceful lives among the tree's branches are endangered by sinister Zlo, and their only hope is a mismatched, brave team of main heroes, on quest to plant the seed of a new tree...

Puzzles mostly follow the trend of increasing difficulty toward the end of the game, but aren't challenging to the point of frustration. Gameplay is very pleasant - interactions between various characters are humorous, and enthusiasm of our little heroes is quite catching.

Background music perfectly suits the mood set by the story. Graphics give me somewhat nostalgic feeling, reminding of some old cartoons and causing to find them mostly cute :)

If you're not averse to simple point'n'click games, you should play Botanicula, it's really lovely :)

There are funny scenes that will definately make you laugh, some impressive sights and vistas that give a sense of awe, and dark scary environments for the 'villains' of the game.  Again, it feels like a well done kid's movie.  I'm not usually a fan of wacky / weird themes like this, especially since I didnt like it in other games like Psychonauts, but I feel like it worked really well here.  The pacing and sound design, which uses a lot of human vocal noise and mixed sound, really helps a lot I think.\n\nThe game runs well, has a good set of options, and a very clean save / load / inventory system.  Since it is a point of note for P+C games, it should be mentioned that it is not possible to game over either.  A good game, but comes in a little short since its no more than 3 or 4 hours long.  I'd still reccommend it.

reviewText:
The sorta kinda well-not-really sequel to the popular Machinarium. Except this time it isn't about scrap and robots but nature and what lives on a tree.

You play as Mr. Lantern and his 4 friends who are trying to save their home, a giant tree, from a parasitic spider-like creature that sucks out the life of said tree and its inhabitants. To do that, they need to bring a seed of the tree down to the ground, a journey that takes them to many interesting locations, situations and characters that are just plain charming and fun to watch. Such as when you encounter a genie and every character has to make a wish, one of them creating a Ferris wheel while the soundtrack by the Hungarian band DVA acoustically stimulates your endorphin production.

The puzzles are much simpler than in Machinarium which actually view as an improvement. I remember getting frustrated with some of the puzzles in that game and even more with the tip function that required you to get past a little shoot-em-up every time you wanted to take a look. On top of that it also had a tendency to just freeze up which is a natural occurrence when you make a game in Flash that is more ambitious and complex than the usual array of games made with it.

Luckily Botanicula doesn't suffer from any of those problems. There are just a few items here and there, other than that the puzzles can be usually solved on the same screen, just like Amanita Design's first two games, Samorost 1 and 2.

The many achievements might lead you to think that Botanicula is rather long, but that isn't the case. The 6 chapters can be played through in about half an hour each. The achievements are related to a little card collecting feature: each new character or creature you meet will give you its card and unlock the corresponding achievement. The majority are mandatory to meet in order to finish the game, but some are optional and require you to find them.

I played the game with such a huge grin on my face. I haven't been charmed by a game like this in a very long time. Easily one of my favorite games of 2012.

reviewText: This is a beautiful game. It is a unique point-and-click adventure. It's not about painfully difficult, unintuitive puzzles, it's about exploring a world brimming with strange creatures and plants. Sometimes just clicking on environmental items at the right time will help you advance. These simple interactions are rewarding in their own way, visually and aurally. There are also some traditional inventory puzzles, and a few simple mini-games along the way. The story is told through images, and if any of the creatures talk, it's in nonsensical gibberish. There is no text, except for in the menus.  Just get it. It's delightful. It's not long, but it's not expensive, either.

Botanicula, the weirdest point & click game I have ever played. Not that I have played lots of these kind of games, but I think it's hard to beat this one in weirdness!

This is a very beautiful game, with light colors and peaceful surroundings. It got some funny-looking creatures aswell, some are actually really cute. Even the bad guys are cute! Botanicula have a very easy and simple storyline, but it's the center of everything. There are no shorter stories or side-tracks at all! Short told, it's all about saving your neighbors and plant a seed safe down on the ground.

The gameplay itself is not that good, it's actually very confusing and complicated. You will lose all sense of direction rather quickly, and some of the tasks are extremly complicated to get correct. It's more about trying to click everything random with a tiny hope to get it right, rather than solving them as you would do with real problems and tasks. It's actually very fustrating, and even boring.
So the challenge is to keep yourself calm through the game, something I for once had problems doing.

To rate this game, and to recommend it or not, is very hard to decide.
I think Botanicum is a game for those experienced with point & click games, with challenging tasks beyond avarage logic.
But I personally will not recommend this game for everyone, giving it a; 2/5

Botanicula is the strangest game I have ever played. I say that with pretty full confidence in my gaming memory. Don’t get me wrong, strange does not by any stretch mean bad. In fact, Botanicula is one of the best games, if not the best, that I have played all year. I love nearly everything about it, down to the absolute simplicity of the story. It’s a tale that’s been done many times before, but never quite like this.

A fantastic tree is the home for many wonderful creatures. Magical life seeds grow from every limb… seeds that allow beings on the tree to live in peace and harmony. One day, a dark entity, one greatly resembling a dark spider, comes and begins to ingest all of the seeds, drawing away all of the life and happiness that the tree houses. It is up to a small group of nuts, seeds, and feathers (yes, you heard me right) to save their home from this evil that has fallen upon them.

It’s an odd take on a classic story. Botanicula takes a step in a direction most games won’t take. They’ve assigned the main roles of their tale to a bunch on inanimate, absolutely regular objects that live in a world of what I can only describe as magic. When was the last time you saw a game that had a feather diving in and out of holes to solve puzzles? It’s a daring move… or just weird, depending on how you view it. It’s a pleasure to play something that’s different, even from most indie games.

Botanicula is a point-and-click adventure game. This is a genre in which I am not very well versed. I’m ashamed to admit that I haven’t played some of the classics, like King’s Quest. Botanicula is more streamlined than traditional point-and-clicks, but that isn’t a bad thing. There was only one or two points in which I truly couldn’t figure out what to do, but sitting there for an hour stuck on one puzzle never got overly frustrating. I never felt like the game was calling me out for being an idiot. If I couldn’t figure out a puzzle and I needed to sit there and solve it without moving, the game wouldn’t do any unnecessary movements or sounds reminding me that I need to move on. I appreciated that more than I thought I would.

Botanicula’s puzzles are a mixture of movement-based solving games, exploration, and fetch quests. Yeah, I know, a game having good fetch quests? Well, but that’s what the genre of point-and-clicks are partially about. I mean, a lot of what they’re about are trying to solve what piece of which goes where. And, if you go back even farther, they are also “how the hell do I pick up this god-forsaken crowbar?” Botanicula doesn’t do that. It doesn’t hold your hand or give you hints, but it gives you as much time as you need to solve a puzzle. You can’t die, you can only be knocked part of the way back. It’s a nice touch.

Exploration is one of the best things about Botanicula. Some areas are completely pointless to the actual puzzle or storyline, but they’re added just so you can experience the beauty that this game truly has to offer. As you look around the tree, you’ll find different creatures and beings that you can interact with. Some of these creatures will give you cards or a pretty display of some kind. Adding the collectable cards into the game gives meandering a purpose, beyond just being a wonderful and rather relaxing pleasure.

I usually save the art design and music for last when I’m in a review, but I simply can’t avoid talking about it any longer. Everything about this game is flooring. Everything. From the silly little sound effects down to the horror that the environment gives you in the later levels. With the exception of Bastion and Badland, I’ve yet to see a game with this quality of art this year.

The music is just indescribable. Really, it’s quite difficult to do. Everything about it gives off a mystic sense, but none of it seems to fit in any one genre. It all sounds like it comes from the same source, which is excellently implemented, as the tree is the centerpiece for the entire game. The music will make you feel what you need to. If you need to feel accomplished in this scene, you will. If you need to feel terrified, you will. If you need to have a feeling of foreboding, believe me, you will. It’s one of the best soundtracks in any game I’ve ever played. Ever.

The game doesn’t have any real talking in it, and I’m 100% okay with that. Dialogue would add absolutely nothing to the game. The story will make you feel for the characters without the use of speech. Sure, there is some humming, or quiet gibberish, or squeals and gasps, but they’re varied and far between. They only happen when they need to. There is no fat in this game. All of it is cut out. You only get what you need; what you deserve.

The sound effects are just as appropriate as the music, clearly. The group you play as has their own sounds that they make, generally as a group. The other characters in the game all make different noises as well, and each one seems to fit the situation perfectly. Some of the sound effects are annoying, but that’s not a bad thing. Except for when you’re stuck on a puzzle in which you have to hear an annoying sound over and over and over.

Visual art is arguably the best part of the game. It’s beautiful. It’s also quite psychedelic. Those two seem to go hand in hand when it comes to good games. Every area on the tree is fitting to the characters in it, and everything feels… right. It’s hard to explain, really. I suppose it’s one of those things that you just need to experience for yourself.

The group with which you play all have different abilities that you can use at certain points, but it’s very rare you do so. This is one of my few complaints with this game. You’re playing as a group of five, but you only use each character’s special properties once or twice. At the end of the game (spoilers) you have to rescue four of the five characters from the dark spider. I would care a lot more about saving them if I felt like each of them had their own personality, and I didn’t really feel that.

Speaking of the giant spiders, they are the perfect antagonist for a game like this. They’re scary, but not scary in the same sense that we humans would find terrifying. Instead they make the characters (and, by proxy, you) feel nervous and uneasy about what they are and why they’re doing what they are. They are silent as well. It’s never explained why the spiders are trying to engulf the tree with darkness, but I think that’s one of the beauties of this game.

In case I haven’t made it clear already, Botanicula doesn’t make much sense. It doesn’t have a pulling backstory like Bastion or a continuous reactionary setting like Badland, but it makes a perfect balance with these games. Badland makes a perfect quick and easy yet puzzling reaction game. Bastion makes you cry and seriously feel for the characters within it, as you help them fight their way back home. Botanicula fills the gap as it sets you on an adventure that you can solve at your own pace, a way to save your home from an evil that’s never truly explained.

I love the fact that Botanicula doesn’t explain everything. It makes the experience so much more innocent. Everything about it makes you want to keep playing, makes you want to explore the homes of hundreds of creatures, makes you want to save your home from a masked villain. Botanicula proves that you don’t need a huge budget to make a game that is truly fantastic. Botanicula is a cute and (almost darkly) atmospheric point-and-click adventure game about little plant creatures following out a mythic quest. (Each of the cute little fellows has their own abilities to help overcome the challenges they encounter, though unfortunately they don't come into play more than a few times :/ Oh well, having a whole group of critters with you is still fun.)

Botanicula is not your usual point-and-click, where you pixel hunt to progress. Instead you'll be searching around for all the cool little creatures that inhabit the world, simply because you *want* to. Seeing them move around and interact (and all the sounds they make!) is really enjoyable, even more so because of how completely optional it is.

Neither will you have to worry about obtuse item combinations to proceed; quest items usually simply frame areas that you'll be exploring, without actually being difficult to collect. The primary difficulty/annoyance comes in the latter half of the game where there are multiple puzzles available at once and you're not sure in what order to do them. Your map is usually good (stylized line drawings on leaves!), although one area in the latter half of the game (the city) is just too jumbled (it's hard to tell where you've been and what's where).

Overall, Botanicula is a great little game (~4 hours, if you explore like I do) with excellent art design, sound design, music, and atmosphere. The first half of the game is particularly good, because of its focus on the environment (both on the natural home of the critters and what's happening to it...); the latter half sort of breaks down on that with one area too cluttered (and discordant with the prior environments) and another too spread out, both too unfocused.

I certainly enjoyed it, though, and I definitely recommend it (though for me the current $10 tag is a bit much; I got it on a Steam sale a while ago - but if you have money, throw it Amanita for me, ok? :P).

Botanicula is the strangest game I have ever played. I say that with pretty full confidence in my gaming memory. Don’t get me wrong, strange does not by any stretch mean bad. In fact, Botanicula is one of the best games, if not the best, that I have played all year. I love nearly everything about it, down to the absolute simplicity of the story. It’s a tale that’s been done many times before, but never quite like this.

A fantastic tree is the home for many wonderful creatures. Magical life seeds grow from every limb… seeds that allow beings on the tree to live in peace and harmony. One day, a dark entity, one greatly resembling a dark spider, comes and begins to ingest all of the seeds, drawing away all of the life and happiness that the tree houses. It is up to a small group of nuts, seeds, and feathers (yes, you heard me right) to save their home from this evil that has fallen upon them.

It’s an odd take on a classic story. Botanicula takes a step in a direction most games won’t take. They’ve assigned the main roles of their tale to a bunch on inanimate, absolutely regular objects that live in a world of what I can only describe as magic. When was the last time you saw a game that had a feather diving in and out of holes to solve puzzles? It’s a daring move… or just weird, depending on how you view it. It’s a pleasure to play something that’s different, even from most indie games.

There was only one or two points in which I truly couldn’t figure out what to do, but sitting there for an hour stuck on one puzzle never got overly frustrating. I never felt like the game was calling me out for being an idiot. If I couldn’t figure out a puzzle and I needed to sit there and solve it without moving, the game wouldn’t do any unnecessary movements or sounds reminding me that I need to move on. I appreciated that more than I thought I would.

Botanicula’s puzzles are a mixture of movement-based solving games, exploration, and fetch quests. Yeah, I know, a game having good fetch quests? Well, but that’s what the genre of point-and-clicks are partially about. I mean, a lot of what they’re about are trying to solve what piece of which goes where. And, if you go back even farther, they are also “how the hell do I pick up this god-forsaken crowbar?” Botanicula doesn’t do that. It doesn’t hold your hand or give you hints, but it gives you as much time as you need to solve a puzzle. You can’t die, you can only be knocked part of the way back. It’s a nice touch.

Exploration is one of the best things about Botanicula. Some areas are completely pointless to the actual puzzle or storyline, but they’re added just so you can experience the beauty that this game truly has to offer. As you look around the tree, you’ll find different creatures and beings that you can interact with. Some of these creatures will give you cards or a pretty display of some kind. Adding the collectable cards into the game gives meandering a purpose, beyond just being a wonderful and rather relaxing pleasure.

I usually save the art design and music for last when I’m in a review, but I simply can’t avoid talking about it any longer. Everything about this game is flooring. Everything. From the silly little sound effects down to the horror that the environment gives you in the later levels. With the exception of Bastion and Badland, I’ve yet to see a game with this quality of art this year.

The music is just indescribable. Really, it’s quite difficult to do. Everything about it gives off a mystic sense, but none of it seems to fit in any one genre. It all sounds like it comes from the same source, which is excellently implemented, as the tree is the centerpiece for the entire game. The music will make you feel what you need to. If you need to feel accomplished in this scene, you will. If you need to feel terrified, you will. If you need to have a feeling of foreboding, believe me, you will. It’s one of the best soundtracks in any game I’ve ever played. Ever.

The game doesn’t have any real talking in it, and I’m 100% okay with that. Dialogue would add absolutely nothing to the game. The story will make you feel for the characters without the use of speech. Sure, there is some humming, or quiet gibberish, or squeals and gasps, but they’re varied and far between. They only happen when they need to. There is no fat in this game. All of it is cut out. You only get what you need; what you deserve.

The sound effects are just as appropriate as the music, clearly. The group you play as has their own sounds that they make, generally as a group. The other characters in the game all make different noises as well, and each one seems to fit the situation perfectly. Some of the sound effects are annoying, but that’s not a bad thing. Except for when you’re stuck on a puzzle in which you have to hear an annoying sound over and over and over.

Visual art is arguably the best part of the game. It’s beautiful. It’s also quite psychedelic. Those two seem to go hand in hand when it comes to good games. Every area on the tree is fitting to the characters in it, and everything feels… right. It’s hard to explain, really. I suppose it’s one of those things that you just need to experience for yourself.

The group with which you play all have different abilities that you can use at certain points, but it’s very rare you do so. This is one of my few complaints with this game. You’re playing as a group of five, but you only use each character’s special properties once or twice. At the end of the game (spoilers) you have to rescue four of the five characters from the dark spider. I would care a lot more about saving them if I felt like each of them had their own personality, and I didn’t really feel that.

Speaking of the giant spiders, they are the perfect antagonist for a game like this. They’re scary, but not scary in the same sense that we humans would find terrifying. Instead they make the characters (and, by proxy, you) feel nervous and uneasy about what they are and why they’re doing what they are. They are silent as well. It’s never explained why the spiders are trying to engulf the tree with darkness, but I think that’s one of the beauties of this game.

In case I haven’t made it clear already, Botanicula doesn’t make much sense. It doesn’t have a pulling backstory like Bastion or a continuous reactionary setting like Badland, but it makes a perfect balance with these games. Badland makes a perfect quick and easy yet puzzling reaction game. Bastion makes you cry and seriously feel for the characters within it, as you help them fight their way back home. Botanicula fills the gap as it sets you on an adventure that you can solve at your own pace, a way to save your home from an evil that’s never truly explained.

I love the fact that Botanicula doesn’t explain everything. It makes the experience so much more innocent. Everything about it makes you want to keep playing, makes you want to explore the homes of hundreds of creatures, makes you want to save your home from a masked villain. Botanicula proves that you don’t need a huge budget to make a game that is truly fantastic. Amanita Design bring us yet another point & click/puzzle game in the form of Botanicula, a very cute and charming story of 5 friends trying save the tree on which they live from a menacing corruption. Along the ride one must solve puzzles using the different abilities of the 5 characters.

The main strength of the game is how beautiful the art is. Everything seems hand-drawn and the animations reflect that, sometimes making movements very cut-out-ish. The music and the sound effects both complement that with very natural sounding tunes (as in involving individual sounds and hums rather than just musical instruments) and cute sounds from the environment (for example, when many different-sized bugs start humming a specific sound, the largest ones obviously humming in deep basses).

The puzzles are relatively simple on average, yet some of the later ones prove to be more complicated than you might imagine for what may strike one as a kid's game. What is unique about Botanicula's puzzles is that it is fun to see what will happen if you click on the wrong character. One problem that I have with the characters though, is that they seem like one entity, meaning it is hard to differentiate them based on their personalities.

This brings me on to how short the game is. It arguably contains 5 areas, each one longer than the one before it (which makes sense because you are moving your way down the tree, where the branches are progressively longer). The objective is to pass an obstacle blocking your passage to the next area by solving puzzles in the current area. There are many optional puzzles and things to click on which add to the completion rate on a playthrough, which does give access to additional content near the end based on how high it is. Even with that the game feels like one that should be completed in one playthrough, and, just like most point & clicks, there is no replay value in the game unless one did not achieve 100% completion.

All in all, Botanicula offers a short, but very charming and beautifully simple experience. Its simplicity can be both an upside and, at times, a downside.

Botanicula is a cute and (almost darkly) atmospheric point-and-click adventure game about little plant creatures following out a mythic quest. (Each of the cute little fellows has their own abilities to help overcome the challenges they encounter, though unfortunately they don't come into play more than a few times :/ Oh well, having a whole group of critters with you is still fun.)

Botanicula is not your usual point-and-click, where you pixel hunt to progress. Instead you'll be searching around for all the cool little creatures that inhabit the world, simply because you *want* to. Seeing them move around and interact (and all the sounds they make!) is really enjoyable, even more so because of how completely optional it is.

Neither will you have to worry about obtuse item combinations to proceed; quest items usually simply frame areas that you'll be exploring, without actually being difficult to collect. The primary difficulty/annoyance comes in the latter half of the game where there are multiple puzzles available at once and you're not sure in what order to do them. Your map is usually good (stylized line drawings on leaves!), although one area in the latter half of the game (the city) is just too jumbled (it's hard to tell where you've been and what's where).

Overall, Botanicula is a great little game (~4 hours, if you explore like I do) with excellent art design, sound design, music, and atmosphere. The first half of the game is particularly good, because of its focus on the environment (both on the natural home of the critters and what's happening to it...); the latter half sort of breaks down on that with one area too cluttered (and discordant with the prior environments) and another too spread out, both too unfocused.

I certainly enjoyed it, though, and I definitely recommend it (though for me the current $10 tag is a bit much; I got it on a Steam sale a while ago - but if you have money, throw it Amanita for me, ok? :P).

Amanita Design bring us yet another point & click/puzzle game in the form of Botanicula, a very cute and charming story of 5 friends trying save the tree on which they live from a menacing corruption. Along the ride one must solve puzzles using the different abilities of the 5 characters.

The main strength of the game is how beautiful the art is. Everything seems hand-drawn and the animations reflect that, sometimes making movements very cut-out-ish. The music and the sound effects both complement that with very natural sounding tunes (as in involving individual sounds and hums rather than just musical instruments) and cute sounds from the environment (for example, when many different-sized bugs start humming a specific sound, the largest ones obviously humming in deep basses).

The puzzles are relatively simple on average, yet some of the later ones prove to be more complicated than you might imagine for what may strike one as a kid's game. What is unique about Botanicula's puzzles is that it is fun to see what will happen if you click on the wrong character. One problem that I have with the characters though, is that they seem like one entity, meaning it is hard to differentiate them based on their personalities.

This brings me on to how short the game is. It arguably contains 5 areas, each one longer than the one before it (which makes sense because you are moving your way down the tree, where the branches are progressively longer). The objective is to pass an obstacle blocking your passage to the next area by solving puzzles in the current area. There are many optional puzzles and things to click on which add to the completion rate on a playthrough, which does give access to additional content near the end based on how high it is. Even with that the game feels like one that should be completed in one playthrough, and, just like most point & clicks, there is no replay value in the game unless one did not achieve 100% completion.

All in all, Botanicula offers a short, but very charming and beautifully simple experience. Its simplicity can be both an upside and, at times, a downside.
